data.name: De Bruijn Sequences - Generation (Part 2)
data.description:
### Background:

A "de Bruijn sequence" `B(k,n)` is a cyclical sequence where *every* possible length-`n` contiguous substring of an alphabet of size `k` occurs exactly once.

A de Bruijn sequence on an alphabet of size `2`, e.g. `0`s and `1`s, consists of 2<sup>n</sup> `0`s and `1`s, such that every substring of length `n`  occurs once. This is a valid de Bruijn sequence `B(2,3)`:

```
00011101
``` 

Each length `3` substring occurs once as a substring: starting from the leftmost `3` digits, moving a `3`-digit window right one digit at a time, and wrapping around, we have:

```
000, 001, 011, 111, 110, 101, 010 , 100
```

### Task:

Given an alphabet size `k`, and a length `n`, return the **lexicographically largest** valid de Bruijn sequence ( of length k<sup>n</sup> ) as a string.

### Conditions:

For this kata, the alphabet size `k` will be between `2` and `8` ( inclusive ). The alphabet will consist of the digits `0 .. k-1`.  
The substring length `n` will be between `2` and `7` ( inclusive ).  

### Required performance:

`O(l)`, where `l` is the length of the output ( i.e. k<sup>n</sup> ).

### Examples:

`(3,2)` should return `"221201100"`.

All of the sequences `"012022110", "001021122", "221201100", "221100201"`  are valid de Bruijn sequences, but only `"221201100"` is the correct solution to this kata, as the lexicographically largest.
  
`(2,2)`  should return `"1100"`
  
`"0011", "0110", "1100", "1001"` are valid de Bruijn sequences, but `"1100"` is the lexicographically largest.
